description.narrative: Stöd till kvinnors politiska representation och inflytande i Burkina Faso, genom bl a utbildningar med kvinnliga politiska ledare, uppmuntran av könskvotering vid politiska val, genderkänslig budgetering i parlamentet, samt en stärkt koalition för genomförande och uppföljning av CEDAW.

Support to women's political representation and influence in Burkina Faso, through for example training women leaders, promoting gender quota during political elections, gender-sensitive budgeting in parliament and a strengthened coalition for implementation and monitoring of the CEDAW.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: This contribution as a whole has led primarily to improved capacities and organisation of women political candidates, but also to strengthened political representation and participation of women in Burkina, illustrated by for example an increase of women in parliament from 13 to 19% after the 2012 elections, although there was a decrease to 9.44% after the elections in 2015, primarily due to remaining inequalities between men and women in the burkinabè society in general impacting upon women's possibilities to be politically active and influence politics. However the programme has led to a strengthened network of women associations and politicians with increased capacities to take joint action, as illustrated by the revised gender quota law, arguing for better positions of women candidates, and the promotion of the CEDAW, resulting in the adoption in 2015 of a new law against gender-based violence against women and girls. In addition to the results above, at the end of the the 18-month program, NDI and its partners realized the following major achievements: 1- Assisted 3,466 women in 10 communes in the province of Houet to obtain their birth certificates, needed to enable them to register to vote in the November 2015 presidential and legislative elections, helping to close the gap between the number of registered male and female voters. 2- Trained women legislative candidates to build skills in communication, leadership and advocacy essential to effective campaigning in order to increase the number of women nominated by their parties as candidates and the number of women elected to public office. Of the 379 prospective women candidates trained, 110 received their party’s nomination as legislative candidates. All 13 women ultimately elected to the National Assembly participated in NDI’s training. 3- Updated a manual for women candidate’s developed before the 2012 elections and distributed it to representatives from 22 political parties, candidates who participated in NDI’s training activities, and government and international partners. 4- Supported newly elected women lawmakers to unite across parties in pursuit of their common legislative priorities by facilitating a series of meetings with key stakeholders including the secretary general, women parliamentarians and members of target committees and networks. 5- With NDI guidance, members of three legislative committees – the General Institutional Affairs and Human Rights Committee (Commission des Affaires Générales Institutionnelles et des Droits Humains - CAGIDH); the Education, Health, Youth, Employment, Social and Cultural Affairs Committee (Commission de l'Education, de la Santé, de la Jeunesse, de l'Emploi, des Affaires Sociales et Culturelles - CESJEASC); and the Finance and Budget Committee (Commission Finance et Budget - COMFIB) – and three legislative networks – the Gender Caucus, Women and Development Network, and the Decentralization and Local Development Network – worked to identify and address their capacity-building priorities in order to focus their efforts to gain skills and experience to be most effective in their legislative duties. 6- Women parliamentarians and CAGIDH members and staffers learned how to use the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) as an advocacy tool to promote equality and women’s rights in Burkina Faso, which is a state party to the convention, alongside national and international legal instruments, enabling and encouraging them to employ these tools at their disposal to promote women’s rights. 7- COMFIB members and staff were instructed in gender-sensitive budgeting, from core concepts to the principal analytical tools for taking gender into account in a budget, with the aim of equipping them to incorporate gender consistently and thoroughly into future state budgets. 8- Women members of parliament (MPs) built their capacity in communication and advocacy to contribute more effectively to the National Assembly’s internal debates and external outreach. The women MPs increased skills in parliamentary communication, working with the media and advocacy. At their own initiative, CAGIDH members worked under NDI guidance in consultation with a civil society organization (CSO) with expertise on human rights to create a parliamentary network on human rights. 9- CAGIDH set up a committee of four MPs to draft the statute and interior rules of the network. to create a parliamentary network on human rights, which was formally launched by the National Assembly shortly after the end of this program. 10- Women MPs gathered to build their capacity in communication and advocacy to contribute effectively and efficiently to the National Assembly’s work, covering communications fundamentals, parliamentary communication, working with the media, and advocacy. 11- The Council of Burkinabe Women (Conseil des Femmes du Burkina – CFB) mobilized members and other women activists to promote application of the women quota law – which requires a 30 percent quota for women on political party candidate lists by political parties in advance of the 2015 presidential and legislative elections and the 2016 municipal elections. CFB’s advocacy and outreach activities targeted party leaders, government officials from the Ministry for Territorial Administration, Decentralization and Interior Security (Ministère de l'Administration Territoriale, de la Décentralisation et de la Securité Interieure - MATDSI), the Independent National Electoral Commission (Commission Electorale Nationale Indépendante - CENI), and the Ministry of Women, National Solidarity and Family (Ministère de la Femme, de la Solidarité Nationale et de la Famille - MFSNF). These discussions were accompanied by awareness-raising activities throughout various regions to rally for women’s increased political participation and representation. 12- Following the presidential and legislative elections, the CFB analyzed the electoral outcomes and produced a report entitled “Gender Analysis of the Legislative Elections of November 29, 2015,” to draw attention to the need to strengthen and better enforce the quota law. 13- Following the municipal elections, CFB conducted a detailed gender analysis containing quantitative and qualitative data, covering the candidates standing for office and election results: “Gender Analysis of the Municipal Elections of May 22, 2016.”
